item.title: IMF Wants Zimbabwe’s Gold-Backed ZiG to Become Sole Currency
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said it would like to see the ZiG “fully becoming a national currency,” as it weighs whether to place Zimbabwe on a staff-monitored program.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: A twenty ZiG banknote

item.title: France’s Finance Minister Is the Calm Hand Macron Needs Now
item.description: Eric Lombard is deploying his deal making skills to avert political turmoil
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Eric Lombard, France's finance minister, at the AI Action Summit in Paris, France, on Monday, Feb. 10, 2025. France is set to announce a total of €109 billion in investment in artificial intelligence projects in the country by companies, funds and other sources over the coming years, President Emmanuel Macron said on the eve of a two-day AI Action Summit.

item.title: US Small-Business Sentiment Increases for First Time This Year
item.description: Sentiment among US small businesses rose in May for the first time in 2025 as firms grew more upbeat about the economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: A hardware store in San Francisco.

item.title: German New Home Prices Rise to Record on Construction Slump
item.description: Prices for new homes in Germany rose to a record in May as housing shortages drive demand, underscoring the urgency facing Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s government to make good on a pledge to boost residential construction.
item.dc:creator: Laura Malsch

media:content.media:description: Apartment buildings under construction in Berlin. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: China and US Holding Second Day of Trade Talks in London
item.description: The US and China resumed talks into a second day in London, with financial markets on edge as the world’s largest economies try to agree to allow exports of key tech and industrial goods and avoid escalating their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick on June 10.

item.title: Weak UK Jobs Data Sends Down Pound and Boosts BOE Rate-Cut Bets
item.description: The pound fell and UK bonds rallied as traders added to bets on interest-rate cuts from the Bank of England after data showed a sharp deterioration in the labor market.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins, Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Britain Loses 276,000 Jobs Since Reeves’ Tax-Raising Budget
item.description: UK employment plunged by the most in five years and wage growth slowed more than forecast, in the clearest sign yet that Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ budget was fueling a deterioration in the British jobs market.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Commuters climb the stairs to exit Liverpool Street railway station in London, UK.

item.title: South Korea Appoints Yeo as Trade Minister to Lead Talks With US
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung appointed Yeo Han-koo, a seasoned trade negotiator, as the new trade minister to guide the country through ongoing tariff talks with the US.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: Yeo Han-koo Photographer: Jean Chung/Bloomberg

item.title: Namibia to Raise $122 Million to Refinance Eurobond Due October
item.description: Namibia plans to raise $122 million in the domestic market to refinance a portion of its $750 million eurobond due October and will use a sinking fund to retire the balance, its Finance Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Kaula Nhongo

media:content.media:description: A road leading to the port in Walvis Bay, Namibia.

item.title: From Visas to Jets, US and China Are Finding New Trade Leverage
item.description: Donald Trump brought many of the same grievances to his second trade war against China, but the economic battleground that’s emerged since then is making it harder to avoid a rupture this time around.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

item.title: ECB Can Still Move Quickly to Adjust Rates, Villeroy Says
item.description: The European Central Bank could still move quickly to adjust interest rates even after an eighth successive cut “normalized” monetary policy, according to Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Francois Villeroy de Galhau Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: China Sends Two Aircraft Carriers Into Pacific Ocean in a First
item.description: Japan said it observed two Chinese aircraft carriers and supporting warships operating simultaneously near remote Japanese islands in the Pacific Ocean for the first time, a new demonstration of Beijing’s advancing naval capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Mari Kiyohara

media:content.media:description: The Shandong aircraft carrier at a naval port in Sanya in 2019. Photographer: Li Gang/Xinhua/Getty Images

item.title: Zambia Sees Economic Growth Surging to Highest Since 2021
item.description: Zambia’s economy will expand at least 6% this year as Africa’s second-largest copper producer reaps the benefit of improved rainfall and higher metal production, the finance minister said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Copper plates on wagons ready for shipping at a refinery in Mufulira, Zambia.

item.title: Norway’s Core Inflation Slows More Than Forecast to 2025 Low
item.description: Norway’s underlying inflation rate declined slightly more than expected in May, cementing the case for Norges Bank to begin interest-rate cuts in coming months.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

item.title: BOJ’s Ueda Says Inflation Is Still Below Target, Weakening Yen
item.description: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the central bank is still some distance from its inflation goal in comments that helped accelerate a weakening of the yen.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Mia Glass

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 1. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged while pushing back the timing for when it expects to reach its inflation target amid intensified uncertainties due to US tariff measures. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Xi Urges South Korea’s Lee to Help Safeguard Free Trade
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping held his first phone conversation with South Korea’s newly elected President Lee Jae-myung and called for cooperation to safeguard multilateralism and free trade.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Lin Chen

media:content.media:description: South Korean flags fly in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024. South Korea's Constitutional Court has started reviewing President Yoon Suk Yeol's impeachment case, while investigators reportedly plan to question him this week over his shock martial law declaration. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Ishiba Pledges 50% Pay Rise by 2040 Ahead of Elections
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has set pay raises and a ¥1 quadrillion ($6.9 trillion) economy as the top campaign promises for this summer’s upper house election, as the date nears for voters to give their latest verdict on his administration.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: New Zealand’s Willis Wants RBNZ to Add Summer Rate Decision
item.description: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis wants the central bank to increase the frequency of its rate decisions, ending its practice of a three-month summer break and bringing it in line with global peers.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett

media:content.media:description: Nicola Willis, New Zealand's finance minister, during an interview in Sydney, Australia, on Friday, Feb. 23, 2024. Willis has cast doubt on her ability to return the budget to surplus by 2027, saying the weakening economy is likely to impact on tax revenue.

item.title: Australia’s Consumer Sentiment Rises in ‘Cautious Pessimism’
item.description: Australia’s consumer confidence edged up in June as the conflicting moves of lower interest rates and cool inflation ran up against slow growth and ongoing trade upheavals to place households in a holding pattern.
item.dc:creator: Michael Heath

item.title: Ireland Needs Fiscal Rule as Economic Risk Grows, Watchdog Warns
item.description: The Irish government should commit to a domestic fiscal rule so it can better plan spending as the economy enters uncertain territory, the state’s fiscal watchdog warned.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: Sunrise over the River Liffey in Dublin, Ireland, on Friday, Nov. 22, 2024. Ireland's election will be a big test of how the country handles its cash surplus. Photographer: Paulo Nunes dos Santos/Bloomberg

item.title: Argentina Eases Bond Auction Rules in Aim to Lure More Dollars
item.description: Argentina’s central bank unveiled a slew of measures Monday aimed at helping the South American nation amass more hard-currency reserves, firepower the country needs to defend the peso.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi

item.title: Colombian Inflation Slows More Than Forecast to Lowest Since 2021
item.description: Colombian inflation slowed more than expected in May to its lowest level since 2021, potentially bolstering the arguments of Finance Minister German Avila who is calling for much deeper interest rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Bristow

media:content.media:description: A shopper browses fruit in a food market in Bogota, Colombia, on Thursday, March 30, 2023. Colombia's Central Bank is expected to release interest rate decision, with economists expecting an increase of borrowing costs. Photographer: Nathalia Angarita/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Retail Sales See Smallest Gain Since November as Budgets Hit
item.description: UK retail sales rose in May at the slowest pace in six months, an industry group found, as increasing prices and higher monthly bills squeezed household budgets.
item.dc:creator: Katie Linsell

item.title: BOJ Likely to Ease Tapering Pace of Bond Buys, Ex-Official Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan is likely to slow the pace of tapering its government bond purchases next fiscal year at the board’s upcoming meeting, according to a former BOJ executive director in charge of monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo.

item.title: ECB Rate Pause Until Autumn Makes Sense, Holzmann Tells ORF
item.description: The European Central Bank may be able to keep interest rates on hold over the summer, according to Governing Council member Robert Holzmann.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Robert Holzmann, governor of Austria's central bank, during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Kansas City Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium in Moran, Wyoming, US, on Friday, Aug. 23, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell said the time has come for the Federal Reserve to cut its key policy rate, affirming expectations that officials will begin lowering borrowing costs next month and making clear his intention to prevent further cooling in the labor market.

item.title: US May Exhaust Debt-Ceiling Measures in Mid-August, CBO Says
item.description: The US government could run out of enough funds to meet its financial obligations in a timely manner between mid-August and the end of September, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. Significant changes are in store for President Donald Trump's signature $3.9 trillion tax-cut bill as the Senate begins closed-door talks this week on legislation that squeaked through the House by a single vote.

item.title: Fed Interest Payments Are Likely Here to Stay, JPMorgan Says
item.description: A proposal to eliminate the interest paid to banks that deposit cash at the Federal Reserve risks unleashing tremors across the industry, funding markets and US monetary policy, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co. strategists.
item.dc:creator: Alex Harris

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, D.C., US, on Wednesday, July 6, 2022. The Federal Reserve will unveil details of what policy makers debated last month that may shed light on how they view the near-term path for interest rates amid surging inflation and signs of a slowing economy.

item.title: US, China Hold Trade Talks in London to Address Export Curbs
item.description: Trade talks between the US and China stretched on in London, with the US signaling a willingness to remove restrictions on some tech exports in exchange for assurances that China is easing limits on rare earth shipments.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Catherine Lucey

item.title: Inflation Expectations Declined Across All Horizons, NY Fed Says
item.description: Consumers’ expectations for future price pressures improved across all horizons in May, and households’ pessimism about the labor market somewhat eased, according to monthly survey data released Monday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: A shopper at a grocery store in New York.

item.title: Bank of Spain Cuts GDP Forecast as US Tariffs Cloud Outlook
item.description: The Bank of Spain lowered its 2025 growth forecast for the country, citing a high level of economic uncertainty due to US trade policies.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro
